video_title: What‚Äôs Fueling India‚Äôs Language Wars ? | Vajiram and Ravi
comment_text:
It is natural‚Äîboth intuitively and logically‚Äîfor those who have deep love for the country - to think in favor of a common link language to support national integration.
Just as we have one Constitution, one national flag, national animal, bird, fruit, and game, a shared language can also unify the country.

Myth:  Learning other language would make one lose his cultural identity.
1)	Our food habits have changed over time. We eat foreign foods and beverages which are not a part of our tradition and culture. Did we lose our culture?
2)	Our clothing styles have changed. Does that mean we have lost our culture? 
3)	We started celebrating or at least accepting other religious festivals like Christmas, Eid etc., Did that spoil our culture?  
4)	Foreign Music, dances and literature are being shared and enjoyed. Did that make our culture a lost one? 
5)	Now we have modern education. We go to schools and colleges. Did all this make our culture lost? 
6)	We are using modern modes of transportation, using modern electronic gadgets. Did that destroy our culture? 
7)	We are learning English as a compulsory subject. Did that destroy mother tongues? 
8)	Many students and job seekers learn other foreign languages like French, germen etc. Did they lose their mother tongues? 
9)	If any of the activities ‚Äì so connected to cultural values ‚Äì have not changed or deformed our cultural identity, how come learning a language like Hindi would make one lose one‚Äôs cultural identity?  

Myth: Hindi is difficult to learn. 
1)	Among all Indian languages, Hindi has the highest number of commonly shared words (Of course via Sanskrit).  Hence, less effort is required to learn new words. 
2)	Hindi grammar is simple and is like simple arithmetic which anybody can learn within a couple of months. Grammars of classical languages like Sanskrit and Tamil are harder to learn. 
3)	Hindi, like any other language in India has similar sentence structure ie Subject+ Object + Verb pattern. Like any other Indian language, the word order is of not much significance, giving more freedom in usage. 
4)	Hence, translation from mother tongue to Hindi is easier than English.
5)	Instead of linguistic purism, Hindi can adopt words from all Indian languages to make its pan Indian and enriched vocabulary. 

Myth: Additional burden
1)	During our school days, subjects like computer science, programming, or AI didn‚Äôt exist. But today‚Äôs children learn these new subjects with ease. Similarly, introducing a subject like language learning‚Äîwhich boosts brain function‚Äîwould be highly beneficial for them, and just as easily they would be adopted. 
Fact: Hindi is easier to implement  
1)	Hindi is already spoken by about 43.63% of the total population. This makes Hindi the most common first language in India. 
2)	Approximately 57% of the Indian population, can speak Hindi or a closely related language. This makes Hindi the most commonly known and spoken language in India.
3)	Hindi is also the third most spoken language in the world. 
It would be difficult if anybody starts from the scratch. 

Avoiding the study of Hindi is often driven by politics and the fear that it might overshadow regional languages. But we already study all subjects with English as medium of instruction, and English isn‚Äôt most people‚Äôs mother tongue. Unless somebody purposefully decides not use one‚Äôs mother tongue, it would not perish. So, what real harm would there be in accepting Hindi as a common link language? This is a question every educated Indian should ask and honestly get answers from within.

üôè

video_title: What‚Äôs Fueling India‚Äôs Language Wars ? | Vajiram and Ravi
comment_text:
I don‚Äôt know how much north indian people respect their mother tongue, but in Karnataka, we respect Kannada just like we respect our own mothers. It may be just a medium of communication for you, but for us, it‚Äôs our identity, our culture, and our pride.

India is a strong nation because of its diversity. It is a union of states ‚Äî not because of Hindi, but because of the unity among various languages, cultures, and traditions. Hindi is not the national language; it is just one of the many Indian languages. When Hindi is imposed on us, it feels like our own language, culture, and identity are under threat.

We don‚Äôt want to learn a third language. A two-language policy ‚Äî Kannada and English ‚Äî is enough for us. You may ask, why learn English, a British language, but not Hindi, an Indian language?

The truth is, India as a single political entity came into being only because of the British. Without them, this land would have remained a subcontinent of many kingdoms, cultures, and languages ‚Äî and that‚Äôs not something to be ashamed of. It‚Äôs our history.

We learn English because it opens global opportunities, helps us get better jobs, and improves our future. But what do we gain by learning Hindi? For most of us in the South, nothing. It doesn't help us professionally or socially. So why should we be forced to learn it?

If we don‚Äôt speak, preserve, and promote our language, who will? It's our responsibility to protect our language, not just for ourselves, but for future generations.

comment_text:
National Integration: Imposing Hindi undermines unity by alienating non-Hindi speakers and threatening diverse identities, despite Hindi itself being a relatively new language it has destroyed languages that have existed for centuries longer.

Administrative Uniformity: English already ensures administrative unity; forcing Hindi creates more disruption and inefficiency in other state governments. Union Government must focus on macro unifying policy and not be imposing singular language and religion, they should focus on education, defence, healthcare, all these critical parameters India is lagging almost 20-30 years behind China.

Population Logic: Hindi is not a majority language; imposition marginalizes diverse regional tongues like Awadi, Haryanavi, foreshadowing the linguistic suppression feared by the South.

Cultural Nationalism: Political imposition of Hindi fuels anger and backlash. Every state in south has Hindi Prachara sabhas and in most schools Hindi is taught at least optionally, do not impose, attract people into the language don't minimise another language. Also even Sanskrit makes more sense than Hindi if you want cultural "nationalism", 30% of Hindi is Persian, are we going to follow dead Persian culture now? 

Economic Accessibility: English, not solely Hindi, provides global and national economic opportunities; forcing Hindi limits rather than expands prospects for non-Hindi speakers.
author: @RedLappy

comment_text:
‚ÄãLaugh all you want, but the truth doesn‚Äôt change. Awadhi, Bhojpuri, Braj, Magahi, Maithili, and dozens more were once thriving languages, not ‚Äúdialects.‚Äù Hindi was artificially elevated post-independence, and these rich languages were lumped under it and erased from official use without consent.
Maithili is still recognized as a separate language in the Constitution. What about the rest? Buried under ‚ÄúHindi‚Äù for political convenience. North India didn‚Äôt just adopt Hindi, it lost its own voices to it...
So yeah, North India was the first victim. If that‚Äôs funny to you, maybe history isn‚Äôt your strong suit.

‚Äã@gauravmishra1671
author: @krillin3350

video_title: What‚Äôs Fueling India‚Äôs Language Wars ? | Vajiram and Ravi
comment_text:
You may laugh, but the reality remains: Awadhi, Bhojpuri, Braj, Magahi, Maithili, and many more were once widely spoken and culturally rich languages. After independence, they were grouped under Hindi in the name of simplification, which led to their decline in official and educational spaces.
Maithili is still listed separately in the Constitution, why not the others? Because they were sidelined, not because they were dialects. North India didn‚Äôt just embrace Hindi, it unknowingly let go of its own linguistic roots.
If that's funny to you, maybe it's time to revisit some real history.‚Äã@gauravmishra1671

I remember when I was in 5th grade (9 years old), there was a short story about Winston Churchill, written by himself. I don't remember if that was just a small part of a larger autobiography or not. That story was about Churchill preparing for an exam and how he had passed it with zero preparation but sheer luck. That story portrayed us how Churchill was a winner and a visionary man. I didn't know the whole truth about Churchill until I started digging about colonial India and the British empire back then. At this point of time, I was roughly 20 years old (during lockdown).

So, for about 10 years I thought how great a man Churchill was.

Stories that protagonize these colonials should be removed from our curriculum!

He often starts with the words, "the GDP of India was 25% of the world's". He forgets to mention that its population, too, was 25% of the world's.¬†So, we weren't extraordinarily rich, the impression he tries to give.

Then I asked Gemini, based on the census of India in 1881, what % of the population were Shudras and Untouchables. It gave a ball park figure of 55 to 65%. video_title: Imperial Receipts with Dr Shashi Tharoor | Episode 1: The Empire
comment_text:
I think we need to be a little more nuanced and careful with the facts than is done here by the eloquent Dr. Tharoor. If it is biased to one side, an informed person can embarrass us when we share this. 

1) Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1928 at St. Mary's Hospital in London, where he worked as a bacteriologist. He got the Nobel Prize for this in 1945. He came to India only in 1953, 2 years before he died. 

2) As for education, the two centers mentioned most often - Nalanda (Bihar) and Taxila (modern day Pakistan) - were non-existent for centuries. Historian D.N. Jha from the University of Delhi mentions that the Buddhist center Nalanda was destroyed by 2 Hindu monks in the 12th century, while Taxila was abandoned in the 5th century. What is now IIT Roorkee was set up by the East India Company's Lieutenant-Governor of the North-Western Provinces, James Thomason as the first engineering institution in India in 1847. It was to help train people to build the Ganges Canal, and named by Proby Cautley as the Thomason College of Civil Engineering in 1854.


3) As for the size of the economy, it should be noted that the industrial revolution started ~1750 in England. Per Nobel laureates Daron Acemoglu and James Robinson in Why Nations Fail, mechanization affected workers in England (as much as anyone else), many of whom revolted (the Luddites) to destroy machinery. It is therefore a tad too convenient to say the British rule destroyed the Indian economy to its own gain. While the Indian economy definitely suffered due to many policies of the EIC, a natural experiment to consider is the comparison of India and China, the two largest economies in 1700. One was ruled from 1757 by the EIC, and the other never was. Both fell in economic size. It indicates that the British rule could not be the factor. In fact, a tiny portion of China ruled by the British - Hong Kong - went on to be 27% (per the World Bank) of the size of the entire Chinese economy in 1993.

video_title: Imperial Receipts with Dr Shashi Tharoor | Episode 1: The Empire
comment_text: Dr Tharoor is used to lecturing an audience completely untutored in the history of British India and consequently is confident that his pastiche of nationalist myths and invented British atrocities will be believed. I however, have studied Indian history and this video did not impress me - except for the audacity with which he tells stories that he himself knows are absolute tommyrot. His version of history consists of a series of assertions, without argument or proofs. For instance his recollection of the history of the British railway system is almost completely false. Indians benefited directly because it was built by Indian labourers who were well paid. Indians took advantage of the railways immediately to travel to visit relatives and to make pilgrimages with a convenience, speed, and a cheapness of travel never before imaginable: the advantages to Indian culture were incalculable. Indians were not herded into rail cars like cattle, on the contrary, the British designed cars especially to accommodate the rules of caste. 3/4 of Indian passengers travelled for free, by riding on the roofs of the rail cars, it is surprising they made a profit. By the 1880s the rail network penetrated to almost every minor town with a market, which allowed the average ryot access to overseas markets for his rice or cotton and average agricultural income increased by 18%.. The same network allowed the British govt to move food in bulk rapidly, and to combat famines effectively for the first time in Indian history - under the Mughal Empire no attempt was made to deal with famine, they just let the peasants die. By 1947 there were 19,000 miles of railways in India, while in China there were less than 4000 miles. Tharoor avoids mention of the vicious social oppression inherent in the caste system, or the many social atrocities connected with both Hinduism and Islam; such as purdah, sati, child marriage, female infanticide, and human sacrifice. The British were very reluctant to legislate against deep seated Indian customs which they personally found repugnant; they believed that fair government had no place interfering in indigenous custom or religion. Thus it was not until the 1820s that female infanticide was abolished, the 1860s that sati was abolished, both passed against the strenuous opposition of the Hindu establishment. It was not until 1910 that a law was passed forbidding the consummation of a marriage with a girl under the age of 12 years; an ancient custom that all members of the Indian Congress, including Gandhi, approved of. For Tharoor to claim that these gross cultural enormities would have been eradicated sooner or later by Indians themselves, ignores the fact that when these practices were suppressed by the British, the most influential and powerful Indians of the time fought tooth and nail to preserve these customs. Tharoors' claim that the Indian economy in 1650 produced 25% of the world GDP but had sunk to only 2% by 1900 "because the British had looted India of trillions" is another lie: the actuality is that since 1650 Europe's capitalist economy had expanded rapidly by 800%, while India's traditionalist economy had stagnated at the level of 1650. Modern India owes everything to British colonial rule. No amount of propaganda by India's historical community - the laughingstock of the world - can change that.  Read this comment and then try and watch the rest of his series with any sense of belief. I am willing to debate anyone, including Dr Tharoor himself.
author: @earlmoorhead915

No one should trust a history book written by a politician: a politician's key talent is to present his political ideas as authentic, when they are invariably a web of deceit. Tharoor is a charlatan and a racist; and he should be ashamed of himself for presenting such misleading material as genuine history and pretending that he is saying something original - when all his claims have been said by every Indian nationalist since 1947. It is all utter nonsense.

video_title: Imperial Receipts with Dr Shashi Tharoor | Episode 1: The Empire
comment_text: Well Tharoor fails to tell you most of what Britain gave to India. Madras, Calcutta, Bombay. The transformation of the economy from a medieval to a modern capitalist economy: with Indian merchants solely dominating the interior trade and Indian merchants  sharing in the coastal/port trade. The creation of a money economy replacing a barter economy. Commercial innovations like the Corporation, joint stock companies, limited liability, sinking funds, national bank, national debt, stock exchange. The substantial expansion of the textile industry by creating a vast overseas market in Europe, Indonesia, Japan. Peace throughout the whole of India for the first time in history, which brought security and thus increased economic activity.  Newspapers, printing, the railway system, vast irrigation canal systems in the Punjab and Gangetic Plain (largest canal system in the world), the telegraph and telephone system. The first universities (free tuition). The unification of the whole peninsula into a single political unit for the first time. The establishment of the "fixed rent or tax" per acre throughout India, which curtailed rack-renting by Indian landowners (all taxes and rents were directly collected by wealthy Indians, NOT BY THE BRITISH THEMSELVES). The first government efforts to combat famines, which  with the railway system, became effective for the first time in history. The first census. The first scientific survey of the whole country. The gradual abolition of some of the medieval practices of Islam and Hinduism, female infanticide, sati, the consummation of marriage with child brides under the age of 12 yrs. The end of centuries of invasion of the north half of India by barbarians from Afghanistan, Ubekistan, Persia. The reason why India in 1947 was the most industrially advanced nation in Asia after Japan was, that the British introduced the beginnings of modern industry in the 1880s, such as steel smelters and mills near Bombay, steam cotton-weaving mills at Bombay, steam ship construction and steam navigation - all being British-Indian partnerships. A vast input of capital from England for commercial investment. The Indian Army, which spread the cash nexus to small villages where the sepoys sent their money home. The first codification of Mughal law into a system. The establishment of a nation wide judicial system based on English common law and some Hindu and Muslim customary law, which for the first time in history gave equal justice to every Indian no matter what their caste, including the 25% outcastes. The rescue of Sanskrit and the Vedas, and the Bagavad Gita from complete oblivion, their publication and their teaching, and the complete rejuvenation of Hinduism in the 1800s as a result. Modern medicine, hospitals, mass vaccinations. The gradual election of Indian leaders (1930s) into the parliamentary assemblies in each state to teach them the rudiments of democratic politics and democratic rule which was to lead to the planned independence of India as a Dominion by mid 20thc (but which plan was ruined by the Indian Congress) & without which India would probably not have become a democracy at independence. The rule of modern English law, which allowed Gandhi and the National Congress the freedom to lead mass political demonstrations and protest strikes legally. (in 1935 Hitler asked the British ambassador why didn't the Brits just execute Gandhi?).  The establishment of the Indian Civil Service (partly English mostly Indian) which was the most efficient and incorrupt civil service in the world. The defense of India from Japan in WWII, when Japan had conquered next-door Burma, and desired the vast coal and iron reserves of India.

video_title: Imperial Receipts with Dr Shashi Tharoor | Episode 1: The Empire
comment_text: Sorry but Dr Tharoor also knows that he has been unnecessarily blowing this , a book and then a celebrated speech probably were not enough. Couple of points. British and the east india company were not a philanthropic set up and came here to make money. Few points : they never exceeded a couple of lakhs and we participated in crores to support them. All of police and admin was india, including all the brutal killings, lathi charge, 1857s inhuman punishment to Jallianwala bagh, all done by our own. Why would somebody not expose these? Anyway now most are dead. Second there would have been no india as a nation if they would not have united us. Of course they united us for their own commercial purpose but our leaders grabbed it. Else we would have had these multi sized kingdoms fighting like cats and dogs. Third we were lucky that we had British , less savage than the Dutch, French, Spanish, Belgians or even Japanese or Russians. They were cruel but not like these.  Fourth they gave us modern institutions, and we can‚Äôt blame all creations for exploitation. Geographically survey of india , ASi , post office, and so many others. Now one can‚Äôt say all these were to exploit our country. Some may have but flip side was far more beneficial to us. Why did all the great kings not establish these ? Some like Jaipur did. Bit too small to have an impact and here and there. They gave us the modern law, wasn‚Äôt there . They could have done easily  without it. They were ruling. Even for semblance of civility and order they did , was of immense use to us. And we had many good judges and many good Judgements. Many are quoted even today. They brought us modern education and English. Else we would have been good at our religious and cultural studies but not fit for the modern world. Look at China for example. I can go on and on. My point is they were here to exploit our resources. We did not have the power , unity or the will to fight them. Post Shahjahan those were lost centuries. Don‚Äôt see a point blaming looters. Look at the benefits, a positive offshoot and move ahead . No long in milling that cow over and over again !

video_title: Imperial Receipts with Dr Shashi Tharoor | Episode 1: The Empire
comment_text:
A Western-friendly aesthetic deployed to ‚Äúwesternize‚Äù an Indian agenda gains nothing from the ceremonial apology of a monarch of a bygone empire. The British crown‚Äîirrelevant now except as pageantry‚Äîwas never so ‚Äúformal‚Äù in life as it is in its afterlife, embalmed in sentiment and ritual. To demand apology from such an institution is to lend it renewed legitimacy, to clothe it in a dignity it scarcely merits.

Tharoor‚Äôs reliance on cherry-picked examples‚Äîforgets post-colonialism, the ‚Äúslowness‚Äù of modernization in but a few railway corridors‚Äîreduces history to anecdote. The railways, built for the English and not the Indians, were no gift, but neither were they useless. Their present decrepitude is not a colonial inheritance but the fruit of corruption, bureaucracy, and decades of neglect. To suggest otherwise is not simply misinformed; it is recklessly bold, as though India were incapable of reasoning except through the paternal voice of the colonizer. And so, when his arguments collapse under the scrutiny of open platforms, what remains is tone-deaf, logically indefensible, as light as air muslin cloth that fiber by fiber will untangle due to the lack of substance in things lacking anything 'dense' Muslin ‚Äì truly a nice pick for someone whose wisdom is as airy and light. Whether he takes the dismantling of his logic as calamities of the most grievous order in stride, absorbing them with the air of a Stoic philosopher rather than a vengeful and howling Banshee, we'll see. Personally, he isn't learned enough to understand anything but I contrasted it with howling Banshees because asking for a formal plea just sounds like the opposite of wisdom and howling banshees, just like they don't exist, neither does what God put between his ears. My mum called it 'Common sense' but I think there is so little of it in his dome, I'd like to rename it 'Rare'
author: @ArwenAreYouOK

They created Hindi because all the other languages used Devanagari script.  While in South Malayalam,  Tamil,  Kannada, Telugu didn't use a common script because of which standardization was not possible. video_title: Language War Explodes: Hindi Imposition vs The Idea of a Diverse India | Democratic Newsroom
comment_text:
how can love for one‚Äôs country be authentic if it doesn‚Äôt include love for one‚Äôs roots‚Äîlanguage, culture, and community? When someone says ‚Äúcharity begins at home,‚Äù it‚Äôs not an act of selfishness‚Äîit‚Äôs a foundation. Likewise, embracing Kannada in Karnataka isn‚Äôt an act of defiance, it‚Äôs an act of identity, of rootedness, and from that rootedness comes the strength to embrace others.

The beauty and challenge of India lie in exactly this: unity through plurality. And that makes this tension deeply Indian‚Äîbecause few other countries carry the weight of so many languages, faiths, and traditions within one border. So yes, this friction is almost unique to India, but it‚Äôs also one of its greatest philosophical strengths: the constant balancing act between honoring the local and embracing the national.

Suggesting that not speaking Hindi makes someone unpatriotic is a narrow view of a vast and layered nation. In fact, it may be more patriotic to defend linguistic diversity‚Äîbecause that‚Äôs the soul of India. Just as justice starts next door, and charity at home, patriotism begins with love and respect for one‚Äôs own corner of the nation.

India, after all, didn‚Äôt become a republic of one identity‚Äîit became a federation of many. That‚Äôs not a flaw. That‚Äôs the design.

comment_text:
285 Million people in South India and more than 90%  of them do not know Hindi. That's the population more than the 5th largest country in the world. Majoritarianism never works for the national unity. If English is foreign to you, which you seem to know anyway, Hindi is foreign to South Indians!  Remember , for most part of the history these were separate kingdoms(Whenever these states were part of the common India, countries like Afghanistan was also part of the common nation)!

Now, there are many Indian languages in the top 20 spoken world languages, be it Bengali, Telugu, Punjabi, Marathi, Tamil ..any of them could be the linked language. Would you like it? the difference in percentage is not that great. Would you consider Bengali as Indian language? If you combine with the population of Bangladesh, it's not that different from Hindi when compared against the number of people who know the language.

If you must form a link language, start teaching Manipuri or Naga to everyone, so nobody is really at an advantage!

I am from South India, and have learnt Hindi in school, got 100% marks in 10th. Still I cannot form a sentence right in Hindi, same with everyone i know. Your environment , how close your mother tonge  with  the other language , all these matters to pick up a language.  If you are travelling to a place, be it South of India or south of Europe, it's the responsibility of you the traveler, to learn the basic way of communication in that area.

video_title: Language War in India | How it Hurts the Nation ? | By Aadesh Singh | StudyIQ IAS
comment_text:
Criticizing Hindi or calling it an ‚Äúimposition‚Äù ignores that it‚Äôs the native language for over 40% of Indians. Promoting Hindi isn‚Äôt about disrespecting Tamil, Telugu, or any language‚Äîit‚Äôs about unity in diversity.

Every region has the right to protect its language, but that doesn't mean shaming Hindi-speaking people or blaming them for historical struggles.

Languages shouldn‚Äôt divide us‚Äîthey should connect us. Hindi is part of India‚Äôs soul, just like Tamil, Malayalam, Kannada, and every other tongue.

video_title: Language War in India | How it Hurts the Nation ? | By Aadesh Singh | StudyIQ IAS
comment_text:
It's easy to call Hindi-speaking states "poor" or "underdeveloped" without understanding the centuries of history that led to it.

Northern India acted as the frontline of defense for the entire subcontinent for centuries‚Äîfacing repeated invasions, wars, and destruction from Central Asia, Mughals, and the British. Cities like Delhi, Varanasi, Mathura, and Nalanda were attacked and rebuilt countless times.

In contrast, Southern states remained relatively untouched by invasions and thus had the chance to heal and grow earlier. Their development is admirable, no doubt‚Äîbut it doesn't mean the North is ‚Äúlazy‚Äù or ‚Äúbackward.‚Äù

After independence, North India provided massive tax revenue and manpower to the nation, including the armed forces. But political instability, population burden, and post-partition trauma slowed its recovery.

Before judging the North, learn the full picture. Development is not a race‚Äîit‚Äôs a shared journey. India grows best when every region respects and supports the other.

Let's stop the North vs South mindset, and start understanding how history shaped our present.
author: @siddharthatiwari8328

comment_text:
I am doing my B.Tech in Tamil Nadu. And yes in my college, tamil students literally cannot speak English. They only speak in Tamil. I understand that it's their mother tongue but atleast learn English so as to communicate with people or students coming from outside Tamil Nadu. Same issue is present with college faculties as well. They too are unable to speak English clearly and a lot many times use wrong words and pronunciation that end up in a completely new meaning.

I originally belong to Odisha. I studied from ICSE till 10th and CBSE for 11th and 12th. But I know all three languages - my mother tongue Odia, Hindi, and English. South politicians sight that learning Hindi degrades their mother tongue and culture. Just tell me I have learned all 3 languages. But I can fluently speak my mother tongue as well as write it clearly. Then how come Hindi degrades mother tongue.


Nothing. All these are dirty politics to instill uncertainties in the brains of common man so that they can gather votes on this pretext.

comment_text: While undergoing Training as a Civil Services Trainee in 1979 we had to necessarily opt for learning one language out of Bengali,Gujarati,Tamil, Urdu and possibly some other Indian Language.I am from Bihar so Bengali was known to me,Urdu also was not  difficult to understand, Gujarati is not very difficult to pick up so I opted for Tamil and passed the final Tamil exam.also.I thought I will be able to remember my Tamil by reading Tamil Literature and hearing Tamil on TV but I realized that a Civil Servant's job needs one to use almost whole waking time on Official work and Official meetings and so on.I had gone to Tamil Nadu first time in 1988 on Official visit for 3 days and experienced that almost no one Rly.Porters to Rest House staff to Taxi drivers to Restaurants could not understand Hindi at all.Subsequent visits to Tamil Nadu after a few years one could see almost all categories of people in Hotels, Taxi drivers and Restaurants could understand Simple Hindi and respond in Hindi.Long ago in 1978 I had gone to Badrinath and was sad to find no Road Direction Boards having Tamil and other languages of India.Later when in S.India I found the same situation.We as a nation need to learn to be accommodative of views/capabilities of our own country people  so that we become better aware of our variegated Indian culture, cuisine and so√ßial habits and practices.

I think ground reality is a bit far from what you are saying bro. The instances has to be seen case by case. Also, the sbi manager could have easily called somebody who actually knows kannada and let the conversation continue there, but she chose to fight back and start saying I don't want to learn which triggered things. comment_text: It's unfair to expect South Indians to speak Hindi while North Indians rarely make an effort to learn local languages like Kannada. Why should one language be prioritized over others? Instead of forcing Hindi on others, North Indians should try to learn and appreciate the languages of the regions they interact with. Only then can we truly claim to be a harmonious and inclusive society.

video_title: Hindi DESTROYING South India? | Will Annamalai End the Language War?
comment_text:
In Karnataka, Kannadigas are known for their multilingual abilities and hospitality. We communicate with people from different states, understand their struggles, and support them. But what hurts is when non-Kannadigas show no interest in learning Kannada, or worse, disrespect it by forcefully speaking only Hindi or English and expecting the locals to adapt.

Kannada is not just a language; it is one of the oldest and classical languages of India‚Äîa symbol of a rich culture, literature, and identity. It is not just our pride but also our duty to protect and promote it.

We don‚Äôt impose Kannada when we live in other states. We expect the same respect when others come to Karnataka. Learn Kannada with love, not compulsion. But never disrespect it or impose your language on us. That naturally invites resistance.

Respect is mutual. Serving in Karnataka? Be fair‚Äîlearn Kannada and connect with its people. We will continue to support unity in diversity, but never at the cost of our language and culture.

Boycott Indian Oil, Airtel, Vodafone Idea, Reliance Jio, and all the nationalized banks if you have the guts to do so. These businesses are all based in north India.

Request that none of the Kannada producers, directors, or performers dub your film in Hindi. Request that they refrain from hiring vocalists for Kannada songs, such as Udit Narayan, Sonu Nigam, and Kumar Sanu.

Gandhi Ji's portrait appears on Indian currency; if you have the courage, stop using it. Keep in mind that he was a Gujarati

comment_text: Indians first need to understand that they are a part of one country and one nation with multiple cultures and languages. So they should accept each other and keep aside their egos and bring their hands of cooperation to one another. comment_text:
I don't understand this MF language debate. People who have never read NEP, know nothing about language and history come and dissolve poison in the society.

Under the NEP every child is expected to learn 3 languages, two of which must be indian languages. Usually people learn mother tongue, english and any other indian language (not necessarily hindi). In my case for example, I was tought Nepali(spoken in Sikkim) along with hindi and English. 

People from south  india especially complain that Hindi is being imposed on them, NO IT'S NOT. It's upto states to promote their language. Learn hindi only if it benifits you( though I would recommend since half of the nation speak Hindi). To a Hindi speaker, I would say : try to learn the local language if you ever move to non hindi state, it's not going to harm you, only thing it will do is to aid to your progress.

And if you are not willing to accept this 3 language formula, then India is never going to be united. And slogans such as" Unity in diversity" will be meaningless.

Sir here mentioned that Hindi is difficult compared to Dravidian languages and people from south find it difficult to learn it. He may be right but my point is: You are not expected to learn difficult grammer and complex litrature of the 3rd language, just learn enough to have basic conversation.
And Please do not fall into traps of politicians, they will let country to burn for their vote bank. They are going to divide us based on Religion, caste, language and region. With growing population we have other issues to be concerned about.

video_title: Hindi Imposition Backfires | Regional Parties Double Down On Language Pride | Akash Banerjee & Rishi
comment_text:
Tamil Nadu foresaw these challenges even at the time of independence. They expressed concerns that people from the South might not be treated equally by those from the North and even considered the idea of a separate country. Unfortunately, some of those fears are proving to be valid today.

Why is it that people from the South are expected to learn Hindi, while many in the North show no willingness to educate themselves? Instead, many blindly follow caste-driven and religious political agendas.

It‚Äôs even more hypocritical when some claim that English is a ‚Äúforeign language‚Äù and insist on promoting Hindi, while ignoring the fact that languages like Tamil, Telugu, Kannada, and Malayalam are much older than Hindi.

To those who demand Hindi: why do you educate your children in English-medium schools? Why do you use English for mobile phones, electronics, banking, and IT? If English is so problematic, why is it the backbone of your professional and digital life?

If people don‚Äôt change their mindset and embrace equal respect for all languages and cultures, we may end up facing a real divide between North and South India.

video_title: Hindi Imposition Backfires | Regional Parties Double Down On Language Pride | Akash Banerjee & Rishi
comment_text:
Internal migration across states in India is a natural part of our country's diversity and economic landscape. People from different regions, including the Hindi-speaking belt, often move to other states for better work opportunities. While this movement helps in economic integration, it can sometimes lead to cultural friction when migrants are unwilling to adapt to the local language, customs, or values.

The concern among native residents arises when it feels like their cultural identity is being overlooked or disrespected. Instead of mutual understanding, tensions can grow if newcomers try to recreate their own regional culture without integrating into the local context. It's important for migrants and locals alike to engage in respectful coexistence.

Ideally, state governments should work toward creating balanced development and employment opportunities across all regions. This would reduce the pressure on people to migrate and help preserve local cultures and languages, while still allowing people to work and live with dignity.

In cases where conflict arises, it‚Äôs important to examine the root causes rather than relying solely on media narratives. Emotional or biased reporting can sometimes overshadow the underlying issues, leading to further misunderstanding.

Just as people in the UK or other countries express concerns about preserving their native culture amidst immigration, similar sentiments can exist within Indian states. Recognizing this parallel can help foster empathy and promote better dialogue around internal migration and cultural respect.
author: @sakshipatil7692
